name: P vs NP Problem
explanation: The P vs NP problem asks whether every problem whose solution can be quickly verified (NP) can also be quickly solved (P). P problems can be solved in polynomial time. NP problems can be verified in polynomial time, but we don't know if they can be solved efficiently. If P = NP, many currently intractable problems (like factoring large numbers, solving Sudoku optimally, or protein folding) would become easy. This would break most modern cryptography. Most experts believe P ≠ NP, but no one has proven it. Worth $1 million (Millennium Prize Problem).

examples.problem: What would P = NP mean for cryptography?
examples.solution: Most encryption methods (RSA, AES, etc.) would become breakable, requiring a complete redesign of internet security
steps: Factoring large numbers is in NP
If P = NP, factoring becomes easy
RSA encryption relies on factoring being hard
All current cryptographic systems would be vulnerable
Would need quantum-resistant or new encryption methods

examples.problem: Give an example of an NP problem
examples.solution: The traveling salesman problem: Given cities and distances, find the shortest route visiting all cities
steps: Easy to verify: Check if a route visits all cities and sum distances
Hard to solve: Must check exponentially many possible routes
If P = NP, we could find the optimal route quickly
This would revolutionize logistics, scheduling, and optimization

proof: Status: UNSOLVED. This is one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Despite decades of research, no one has proven whether P = NP or P ≠ NP. The problem is fundamental to computer science and has implications for algorithms, cryptography, and artificial intelligence.
